name: Tomato
description: A warm-season crop prized for its versatile fruit. Requires staking or caging for support. Thrives in rich, well-drained soil with consistent moisture.

name: Pepper
description: Sweet bell peppers that mature from green to red, yellow, or orange. Needs warm soil and a long growing season for full color development.

name: Hot Pepper
description: A popular medium-heat chili pepper. Compact plants produce prolifically throughout summer. Excellent fresh, pickled, or smoked.

name: Cucumber
description: A warm-season vining crop that produces abundantly. Can be grown on a trellis to save space. Keep consistently watered for crisp, non-bitter fruit.

name: Zucchini
description: A prolific summer squash that produces heavily from just a few plants. Harvest young at 6-8 inches for the best flavor and texture.

name: Summer Squash
description: A tender warm-season squash with buttery yellow skin. Bush-type plants are compact and productive. Best harvested young for tender flesh.

name: Winter Squash
description: A long-season squash with sweet, nutty flesh. Stores for months after curing. Vining plants need ample space or sturdy trellising.

name: Pumpkin
description: A sprawling warm-season vine that needs plenty of room. Requires a long, warm growing season. Rich soil and consistent water produce the largest fruit.

name: Corn
description: A warm-season grass that needs to be planted in blocks for proper wind pollination. Heavy feeder that benefits from nitrogen-rich soil amendments.

name: Eggplant
description: A heat-loving crop with glossy purple fruit. Needs a long, warm season and fertile soil. Mulch heavily to retain moisture and keep roots cool.

name: Okra
description: A heat-loving southern favorite that thrives in hot, humid conditions. Produces edible pods best harvested at 2-3 inches. Tolerates drought once established.

name: Artichoke
description: A large perennial thistle grown for its edible flower buds. Prefers mild winters and cool summers. In cold climates, grow as an annual with vernalization.

name: Lettuce
description: A cool-season salad green with tender, buttery leaves. Bolts quickly in heat; best grown in spring and fall. Succession plant every two weeks for a continuous harvest.

name: Romaine Lettuce
description: An upright lettuce with crisp, elongated leaves. More heat-tolerant than other lettuce types. The classic choice for Caesar salads.

name: Spinach
description: A nutrient-dense cool-season green that bolts quickly in warm weather. Best planted in early spring or fall. Tolerates light frost and partial shade.

name: Kale
description: An extremely cold-hardy brassica green that sweetens after frost. Harvest outer leaves continually throughout the season. Rich in vitamins A, C, and K.

name: Swiss Chard
description: A beautiful and productive green with colorful stems. Tolerates both heat and cold better than spinach. Cut-and-come-again harvesting extends the season.

name: Arugula
description: A peppery salad green that matures quickly. Best in cool weather; bolts rapidly in heat. Succession sow every 2-3 weeks for continuous harvest.

name: Collard Greens
description: A heat-tolerant and cold-hardy Southern staple. Large, thick leaves can withstand light frost and hot summers. A nutritional powerhouse in the brassica family.

name: Bok Choy
description: A fast-growing Asian green with crisp white stalks and tender dark leaves. Bolts quickly in heat; best for spring and fall. Excellent stir-fried or in soups.

name: Endive
description: A slightly bitter salad green with frilly leaves. Blanching the inner leaves by tying reduces bitterness. Thrives in cool weather and tolerates light frost.

name: Radicchio
description: A chicory with striking red and white leaves and a pleasantly bitter flavor. Best grown in cool weather for tight head formation. Frost enhances sweetness.

name: Broccoli
description: A cool-season brassica that forms a large central head of green flower buds. After harvesting the main head, many varieties produce smaller side shoots for weeks.

name: Cauliflower
description: A finicky cool-season brassica that needs consistent conditions. Blanch curds by tying outer leaves over the head. Intolerant of temperature swings.

name: Cabbage
description: A hardy cool-season crop that forms a dense head. Tolerates light frost, which can improve flavor. Provides a long storage life when kept cool.

name: Brussels Sprouts
description: A slow-growing brassica that produces miniature cabbage-like heads along a tall stalk. Flavor greatly improves after frost. Needs a long, cool growing season.

name: Kohlrabi
description: An unusual brassica with a swollen stem that tastes like a mild, sweet turnip. Very fast growing and cold-tolerant. Harvest when the bulb is tennis-ball sized.

name: Carrot
description: A root vegetable that needs loose, rock-free soil for straight roots. Slow to germinate; keep soil moist for 2-3 weeks after sowing. Thin seedlings for best results.

name: Beet
description: A dual-purpose crop with edible roots and nutritious greens. Each seed cluster produces multiple seedlings that need thinning. Prefers cool weather and even moisture.

name: Radish
description: One of the fastest-maturing vegetables, ready in as few as 25 days. Perfect for interplanting and marking slow-germinating rows. Best in cool weather.

name: Turnip
description: A fast-growing root crop with edible greens. Best in cool weather for mild, sweet roots. Spring and fall sowings avoid the bitterness that heat causes.

name: Parsnip
description: A sweet, nutty root vegetable that requires patience. Very slow to germinate and needs a long growing season. Flavor dramatically improves after fall frost.

name: Potato
description: Grown from seed potatoes rather than true seeds. Hill soil around stems as plants grow to increase yield and prevent green tubers. Needs loose, acidic soil.

name: Sweet Potato
description: A warm-season root crop grown from slips. Needs a long, hot season and loose, sandy soil. Excellent for southern gardens; can be grown in raised beds further north.

name: Onion
description: Grown from seed, sets, or transplants. Requires proper day-length variety selection for your latitude. Long-day for the north, short-day for the south.

name: Garlic
description: Best planted in fall for a summer harvest. Hardneck varieties produce scapes and are better for cold climates. Softneck types store longer and suit mild winters.

name: Leek
description: A mild, sweet allium that takes patience to grow. Hill soil around stems for longer white shanks. Very cold-hardy and can overwinter in many climates.

name: Shallot
description: A gourmet allium with a delicate, complex flavor. Can be grown from sets or seed. Prefers rich, well-drained soil. Stores well for months after curing.

name: Peas
description: A cool-season climber with edible pods and sweet peas. Provide a trellis or support. Fix nitrogen in the soil, improving it for future crops.

name: Green Beans
description: A warm-season legume that is easy to grow. Bush varieties need no support, while pole types yield longer. Fix nitrogen in the soil for subsequent crops.

name: Lima Beans
description: A warm-season legume that needs a longer season than green beans. Requires warm soil to germinate. Both bush and pole varieties available.

name: Edamame
description: Immature soybeans harvested when pods are plump and green. A warm-season legume that needs 2-3 months of hot weather. High in protein and easy to grow.

name: Basil
description: The classic culinary basil with large, fragrant leaves. Extremely frost-sensitive. Pinch flowers to extend leaf production and prevent bitterness.

name: Cilantro
description: A fast-bolting herb that produces both cilantro leaves and coriander seeds. Best in cool weather; succession sow every 3 weeks. Self-sows readily in the garden.

name: Parsley
description: A biennial herb with flat, flavorful leaves. Slow to germinate; soak seeds overnight to speed things up. Frost-tolerant and productive over a long season.

name: Dill
description: A tall, feathery herb with both edible leaves and seeds. Attracts beneficial insects. Direct sow in place, as it resents transplanting due to a taproot.

name: Oregano
description: A hardy perennial herb with intensely aromatic leaves. Spreads readily and is drought-tolerant once established. Flavor is strongest just before flowers open.

name: Thyme
description: A low-growing perennial herb that thrives in poor, dry soil. Excellent as a ground cover or border plant. Many culinary and ornamental varieties available.

name: Rosemary
description: A woody perennial herb with aromatic needlelike leaves. Needs excellent drainage and dislikes wet feet. Can be overwintered indoors in cold climates.

name: Sage
description: A shrubby perennial herb with velvety, gray-green leaves and a warm, earthy flavor. Drought-tolerant once established. Cut back woody growth in spring.

name: Mint
description: A vigorous perennial herb that spreads aggressively by runners. Best grown in containers to prevent it from overtaking the garden. Thrives in moist, shaded areas.

name: Chives
description: A hardy perennial allium with mild onion-flavored hollow leaves and edible purple flowers. Easy to grow and virtually maintenance-free. Divide clumps every few years.

name: Lavender
description: A fragrant perennial herb with silvery foliage and purple flower spikes. Demands excellent drainage and alkaline soil. Attracts pollinators and deters deer.

name: Tarragon
description: A perennial herb with a distinctive anise-like flavor essential to French cuisine. Must be grown from divisions or cuttings; true French tarragon does not come true from seed.

name: Strawberry
description: A perennial fruit that produces runners freely. June-bearing types give one large flush; everbearing types produce throughout the season. Mulch to protect from cold.

name: Watermelon
description: A sprawling warm-season vine that needs plenty of heat, space, and water. Sandy soil warms faster and promotes good drainage. Ripe when the belly spot turns yellow.

name: Cantaloupe
description: A warm-season melon with sweet, orange flesh and netted rind. Ripe when the stem slips easily from the fruit. Needs rich soil, warm nights, and consistent water.

name: Honeydew
description: A warm-season melon with smooth, pale green skin and sweet flesh. Slower to mature than cantaloupe, needing a long, hot season. Harvest when blossom end softens.

name: Celery
description: A challenging cool-season crop that demands constant moisture and rich soil. Long growing season of 130+ days. Blanch stalks by hilling soil or using cardboard collars.

name: Asparagus
description: A long-lived perennial that produces spears in spring for 15-20 years once established. Plant crowns in a deep trench. Do not harvest for the first two years.

name: Fennel
description: Grown for its crisp, anise-flavored bulb. A cool-season crop that bolts in heat. Best planted in late summer for a fall harvest. Many plants dislike growing near fennel.

name: Scallion
description: A quick-growing green onion harvested before a bulb forms. Succession sow every few weeks for a steady supply. Very cold-tolerant and easy to grow.

name: Tomatillo
description: A relative of the tomato enclosed in a papery husk. Essential for salsa verde. Needs at least two plants for cross-pollination. Tolerates heat and some drought.

name: Rutabaga
description: A cross between turnip and cabbage with sweet, golden flesh. Needs a long, cool growing season and improves after light frost. Stores exceptionally well.

name: Celeriac
description: Celery root, a knobby root vegetable with concentrated celery flavor. Very long growing season but low maintenance once established. Excellent roasted or in soups.

name: Daikon Radish
description: A large Asian radish that can grow over a foot long. Excellent for breaking up compacted soil. Best planted in late summer for a fall harvest.

name: Mizuna
description: A mild Japanese mustard green with feathery, serrated leaves. Extremely fast growing and cold-hardy. Excellent in salads or lightly wilted. Slow to bolt.

name: Mustard Greens
description: Peppery, spicy greens that grow quickly in cool weather. Many colorful varieties including red and purple. Young leaves are milder; mature leaves pack heat.

name: Pole Beans
description: Climbing bean variety that produces over a longer season than bush types. Requires sturdy poles, teepees, or trellises. More productive per square foot than bush beans.

name: Lemongrass
description: A tropical grass with a bright citrus flavor essential to Southeast Asian cooking. Grow as an annual in most climates. Easily propagated from grocery store stalks.

name: Chamomile
description: A self-sowing annual herb grown for its apple-scented daisy flowers used in tea. Attracts beneficial insects and is said to improve the health of nearby plants.

name: Sunflower
description: A cheerful annual grown for its seeds, oil, and ornamental value. Tall varieties can serve as a living trellis for pole beans. Attracts pollinators and birds.

name: Ground Cherry
description: A small, sweet fruit in a papery husk related to tomatillos. Prolific plants drop ripe fruit to the ground. Tropical, pineapple-like flavor. Self-sows in warm climates.

name: Rhubarb
description: A cold-hardy perennial with tart, edible stalks; leaves are toxic. Needs winter chill to thrive. Produces for decades once established. Harvest stalks but never remove more than a third.

name: Watercress
description: A peppery aquatic green that thrives in cool, flowing water or consistently wet soil. Rich in vitamins and minerals. Can be grown in containers with a saucer of water.

name: Sorrel
description: A tangy, lemony perennial green that is one of the first to emerge in spring. Extremely cold-hardy and easy to grow. Wonderful in soups, sauces, and salads.

name: Nasturtium
description: An edible flower with peppery leaves, blossoms, and seed pods. Serves as a trap crop for aphids. Trailing varieties work well as ground cover or in hanging baskets.

name: Marigold
description: An annual companion flower whose roots exude compounds that repel nematodes. Plant throughout the vegetable garden as a pest-deterrent and pollinator attractor.

name: Ginger
description: A tropical rhizome prized for its spicy, aromatic root. Grows well in containers or shaded garden beds with rich, moist soil. Plant rhizome pieces with eye buds 2 inches deep. Harvest after 8-10 months when leaves yellow.

name: Dahlia
description: A tuberous perennial grown as an annual in most zones, prized for showy blooms in nearly every color except blue. Plant tubers 4-6 inches deep after last frost when soil reaches 60F. Dig and store tubers in fall in zones 3-8.

name: Zinnia
description: An easy-to-grow annual flower that blooms prolifically in nearly every color. Excellent cut flower that attracts butterflies and pollinators. Deadhead spent blooms to encourage continuous flowering.

name: Cosmos
description: A carefree annual flower that thrives on neglect. Feathery foliage topped with daisy-like blooms in pink, white, orange, and crimson. Attracts butterflies and beneficial insects. Self-sows readily.

name: Snapdragon
description: A cool-season annual with spiky flower stalks in a wide range of colors. Tolerates light frost and blooms best in spring and fall. Excellent cut flower with a long vase life. Pinch tips for bushier growth.

name: Petunia
description: A popular bedding annual with trumpet-shaped flowers in almost every color. Blooms continuously from spring until frost. Wave and trailing types are excellent for containers and hanging baskets.

name: Morning Glory
description: A vigorous annual vine with trumpet-shaped flowers that open fresh each morning. Quickly covers trellises, fences, and arbors. Self-sows readily and can become aggressive in warm climates.

name: Sweet Pea
description: A fragrant climbing annual with delicate butterfly-like flowers in pastel shades. Thrives in cool weather and fades in summer heat. Provide a trellis or netting for support. Sow seeds early for best results.

name: Pansy
description: A cheerful cool-season annual with face-like blooms in a rainbow of colors. Tolerates light frost and thrives in spring and fall. Edible flowers make lovely garnishes. Fades in summer heat.

name: Hollyhock
description: A stately biennial with tall flower spikes reaching 5-8 feet. Blooms in its second year with large, papery flowers in many colors. Classic cottage garden flower that self-sows freely.

name: Gladiolus
description: A showy summer-blooming corm with tall sword-shaped flower spikes. Plant corms in succession for continuous blooms. Dig and store corms in fall in zones colder than 7. Excellent cut flower.

name: Black-Eyed Susan
description: A cheerful native perennial with golden-yellow daisy-like flowers and dark brown centers. Blooms from midsummer to fall. Drought-tolerant once established and beloved by pollinators.

name: Coneflower
description: A hardy native perennial with large daisy-like flowers featuring raised coppery-orange centers. Blooms midsummer through fall and attracts butterflies, bees, and goldfinches. Extremely drought-tolerant once established.

name: Peony
description: A long-lived perennial with extravagant, fragrant blooms in late spring. Can thrive for decades with minimal care. Plant roots in fall with eyes just 2 inches below soil surface. Requires winter chill to bloom.

name: Blueberry
description: A fruit-bearing shrub producing sweet, antioxidant-rich berries in midsummer. Requires acidic soil (pH 4.5-5.2) and consistent moisture. Plant two or more varieties for best cross-pollination and larger yields.

name: Raspberry
description: A fruit-bearing cane producing sweet berries in summer or fall depending on variety. Plant bare-root canes in early spring. Everbearing types produce a fall crop on first-year canes. Prune spent canes after harvest.

name: Blackberry
description: A vigorous fruit-bearing bramble producing dark, sweet-tart berries from midsummer to fall. Erect varieties are easier to manage than trailing types. Prune after fruiting and provide a trellis for trailing types.

name: Borage
description: An annual herb with star-shaped blue flowers that attract pollinators. Edible flowers and young leaves have a mild cucumber flavor. Excellent companion plant that deters tomato hornworm and cabbage worms.
